text: [Music]
you're going to prison as a young man
you come out as an adult and then you've
got to pick up relationships with your
family friends and people who you have
sort of become friends with whilst
you're in prison and you are a different
person
you know they my family for example
experienced me going in as a young man
when I came out I was an editor so they
didn't know how to interact with me I
didn't know how to interact with them
and remember when you're in prison I was
in the British prison system for 12
years I only interacted with men for 12
years so building relationship with
females can also improve very very
difficult and then there's the the
everyday things walking up to a door and
attempting to open a door you've not
done that for 12 in this case 30 years
so you forget how to do those simple
things and that is traumatizing you know
regardless of the physical aspects of
being locked up there is the
psychological aspects and you never
overcome those those mental scars mess
around so deep we just saw Glen Ford
there saying when I went inside I had
babies now they've got babies how was
that for your friends and family
difficult for you but also for everyone
involved you lose your friends you know
in my circumstance you know most of the
people I knew when I went into prison
our friendship ended while I was in
prison so when I came out they were no
longer my friends so you're trying to
build friendships with people who
already have their friends they're
already in relationships with friends
you try and penetrate that and it's very
difficult because you are a different
person to them they may have gone
through University College they may have
lived their life you haven't you've been
confined in a space for a very long time
and so you're you're consumed in your
own world what does that deep sense of
injustice do to you I think when you're
innocent in your imprison you're bitter
you're bitter for the duration of the
time that you're in prison it's very
difficult when you come out to sort of
shake that off but it's important that
you do because if you remain bitter you
cannot get on with your life because
you're continuously fighting something
that's no longer there emotionally it's
very difficult to overcome because it
hangs around you for the rest of your
life you know the impact of spending
that amount of time in prison in my case
12 years in this guy's case 30 years it
never leaves you listen this is one
thing but what about
just that sense of mistrust I mean were
you able to build trust again in our
institutions and even the way the world
is around the judicial system you have
to or you wouldn't be able to function
you know what happened to me what
happened to this guy was probably done
by a certain amount of people not every
police officer not every individual who
gives evidence in a trial is guilty of
doing something of an injustice so you
can it's possible and you have to or you
can't survive such a powerful picture
that we're looking at now the day that
you were released can you describe what
it was like that moment the day I was
released from prison it was a four-day
isn't that a lot of the sun is shining
everything you have well it wasn't
expected you you know remember I've been
in prison for 12 years and even the day
I walked into the court and they said my
convictions were quashed and I could
walk out I didn't expect that to happen
you know that the the system had done
what it had done to me and there was no
indication that my convictions would
ever be quashed you know I was sent to
prison for the rest of my life and all
of a sudden I was released you know
we've I don't know 30 40 pounds in my
pocket and told to get on with my life
there was no sort of cushion no no
safety net it was you know you're out
get on and I did the immediate thing
that I could do which was shout I'm free
and there are other people who are still
in prison or not who are innocent just
watching Glenn Ford when he was released
today after 30 years can you imagine
what the world looks like to him because
presumably in prison you have an idea of
what's going on there's nothing like
actually experience and you don't
actually the world moves on you stay
still I mean 30 years is a very long
time and you know even in the 12 years
that I was in prison when I came out I
was handing a mobile phone for the very
first time and people laughed at me
because I didn't know what to do with it
you know I remember sitting in the back
of a black taxi having just been
released from the Old Bailey and my
sister put a mobile phone in my hand and
I didn't know how to use it you know I
was used to this sort of phone that
comes off of the hook and you hold it
like that and you dial the numbers but
this was a digital thing that I'd never
experienced never experienced the
internet simple things going into shops
you know when this guy goes into a shop
he's going to have a wider range of
choice you know when you're in prison
you have one choice he's going to be
excited by it but depressed by it as
well
when you saw him being released today
and I'm just watching the story now does
it bring anything back for you or how do
you feel I don't think you ever lose
sight of the fact that you've been where
you've been and I've been where I've
been yes I mean he was very composed you
know he's come out he's not screaming
and shouting like I did when I came out
of the call accusing everybody of ruin
in my life he seemed very composed and
and you know just based on that I'm
confident that he will be able to
rebuild his life importantly it's what
happens now over the next 12 months
luckily for me I was able to get a job
at the BBC quite soon and that dictated
the rest of my life there was something
solid in my life to look forward to when
you don't have that it's going to be
very very difficult I I don't for one
minute imagine that after 30 years he is
going to be a proper human being in the
way that he would have been before he
went to prison no question
